Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’m Nina Al-Mansoori. It’s great to meet you!
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Nina! It’s wonderful to meet you too. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m a bit anxious, to be honest. It’s the start of my senior year in graphic design, and I have a lot on my plate.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s completely understandable. Starting a new year can bring both excitement and stress. What’s specifically on your mind?
Dialogue.Student: I’m excited about my portfolio project, but I’m feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to create something standout while keeping up with my volunteer work.
Dialogue.Counselor: It sounds like you’re juggling a lot! Have you had the chance to reflect on how you can manage all these commitments effectively?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I just feel the weight of it all. Plus, I heard my favorite professor is leaving—he’s been a huge support for me.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s tough news. Change can be unsettling, especially when it impacts your support system. How do you think this will affect your motivation going forward?

Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’m back! I’m feeling really isolated this week.
Dialogue.Counselor: Welcome back, Nina! I’m glad you’re here. What’s been making you feel isolated?
Dialogue.Student: I’ve been so focused on my project and helping a friend that I’ve neglected my studies and time with friends.
Dialogue.Counselor: It sounds like you’re really feeling the pressure. Have you found any time to relax or enjoy your hobbies?
Dialogue.Student: Not really. I keep thinking about how much I need to catch up. My friend Sarah is going through a tough time, and I want to be there for her.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s admirable that you want to support Sarah, but it’s also important to take care of yourself. How would you feel about setting small boundaries to maintain your own well-being?
Dialogue.Student: I think that would help, but it feels hard to say no to her when she needs support.
Hi again. I’m feeling pretty defeated today.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Nina! I’m here for you. What’s been bothering you?
Dialogue.Student: I had a class critique today, and when I presented my work, one of my classmates was really dismissive.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m sorry to hear that. It can be really hurtful when others don’t acknowledge your hard work. How did you feel during and after the critique?
Dialogue.Student: I felt humiliated and started to doubt my design skills. It’s like I can’t catch a break.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s totally understandable. It’s important to remember that critiques can sometimes reflect others’ insecurities rather than our abilities. Have you thought about talking to someone about your experience?
Dialogue.Student: I confided in Sarah, but I ended up feeling like a burden instead of comforted.
Hi! I’ve been reflecting on everything lately.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Nina! I’m glad you’re back. What reflections do you have?
Dialogue.Student: I realize I need to confront my classmate and express how their comments affect me. I can’t keep burying my feelings.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s an excellent decision! How are you feeling about this upcoming conversation?
Dialogue.Student: I’m really nervous but hopeful that it could lead to a better understanding. I want to stand up for myself.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a positive mindset! Starting from a place of wanting clarity can help. What’s your plan for initiating the conversation?
Dialogue.Student: I’ll keep it honest and state how their feedback affects my motivation while reinforcing my commitment to the group.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a fantastic approach! Remember, you deserve to have your voice heard as much as anyone else. Let’s reconnect afterward to discuss how it went!
